sentence_text: We therefore insist on the need to fully implement Article 44 of the Charter of the United Nations, which establishes the requirement to invite troop-contributing countries to participate, in an active and binding manner, in the decision-making process with regard to the deployment oftroops in peacekeeping missions.
speaker: Mr. Ramirez Carrefio
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That has never really been operational.
speaker: Mr. Ramirez Carrefio
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That single action could help enormously to prevent and punish this type of reprehensible and despicable crime.
speaker: Mr. Ramirez Carrefio
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In conclusion, having adopted this resolution, we hope that we will never again have to discuss abuses against women, children and the most vulnerable groups in armed conflict.
speaker: Mr. Ramirez Carrefio
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Ukraine welcomes the adoption of resolution 2272 (2016), which we consider to be a milestone document.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We commend the United States delegation for its leadership in that regard.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: During yesterday's debate (see S/PV.7642), the lack of sufficient progress in the fight against sexual exploitation and abuse in the past decade was acknowledged by almost all delegations.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Unfortunately, the number ofallegations has not diminished.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The crimes committed today are as appalling as they were years ago.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We believe that the Security Council is uniquely positioned to send a strong message to confront this problem.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is why we fully supported the adoption of today's resolution.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We hope that the document we have adopted will serve as a clear signal to all parties concerned that the Security Council stands for the pressing need to implement a more assertive approach in order to address the scourge of sexual exploitation and abuse promptly.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As an active troop- and police-contributing country, Ukraine reaffirms its determination to effectively contribute to the fight against sexual exploitation and abuse, to engage with all stakeholders and to implement the necessary steps and mechanisms, including those envisaged in today's resolution.
speaker: Mr. Vitrenko
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Malaysia supports resolution 2272 (2016), which the Council just adopted.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It sends an unambiguous message that the Security Council, the United Nations and the international community will not tolerate sexual exploitation and abuse by peacekeepers.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have repeatedly called for zero tolerance in that regard, and today we have strengthened our resolve on the matter.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We support many of the strong measures initiated by the Secretary-General to strengthen accountability for perpetrators of abuse, as set out in resolution 2272 (2016).
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Malaysia firmly believes that peacekeepers must uphold the highest standards of professionalism and moral values, as they are mandated to protect civilians, and to uphold international humanitarian law and human rights law while serving in areas of conflict.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In our view, the provisions on the repatriation of contingents that demonstrate widespread and systematic sexual exploitation and abuse or non-response to allegations of misconduct are wholly justified.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In that regard, we note that the route leading towards a decision on possible repatriation must come with clear and transparent criteria and guidelines, developed in full consultation and engagement with the concerned troop-contributing countries throughout the process.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In the spirit of renewing and re-energizing the United Nations peacekeeping institutions, we would also stress the importance of trilateral consultations among the Council, troop-contributing countries and the Secretariat.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We regret the missed opportunity to rally consensus around such an important resolution.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We believe that the rationale to address sensitivities surrounding this issue warrant, at this time, engaging the concerned stakeholders, namely, the troop-contributing countries.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As mentioned by many delegations yesterday (see S/PV.7642), combatting sexual exploitation and abuse requires the collective efforts of all members of the United Nations and the international community.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We hope that resolution 2272 (2016) creates the intended momentum to end impunity for sexual exploitation and abuse by peacekeepers.
speaker: Mr. Ibrahim
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Spain thanks the United States for this important initiative.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have just adopted resolution 2272 (2016), the first to address exclusively conduct deemed completely unacceptable.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: With this resolution, the Security Council is sending a strong message to all who have the responsibility to eliminate this scourge, and that responsibility is collective.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: My delegation supported the text put forward in its entirety and without amendment, because quite simply we cannot address the issue of accountability in a partial manner.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The reason for that is obvious.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our aim is not to repatriate contingents, but to protect the victims and prevent the repetition of aggressive acts.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is therefore necessary to investigate such matters as soon as possible or inform the Secretary-General of the measures taken.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The perpetrators must be brought to justice and serve their sentences.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: All of that is first and foremost the responsibility of the troop-and police contributing countries, precisely because we do not want the work of a contingent to be tarnished by the actions of some of its members.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Let us ensure that we all assume our responsibility.
speaker: Mr. Oyarzun Marchesi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I thank the United States delegation for having taken the initiative of submitting to the Security Council the text of resolution 2272 (2016), which we have just adopted, concerning cases of sexual exploitation and abuse committed by United Nations peacekeeping personnel and external forces authorized by the Council.
speaker: Mr. Seck
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As a troop- and police-contributing country and in accordance with its international commitments to peacekeeping and respect for international humanitarian law and international human rights law, Senegal naturally voted in favour of the resolution.
speaker: Mr. Seck
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The delegation of Senegal participated actively in the negotiations in a constructive spirit and accordingly proposed amendments aimed at making the text clearer with a View to ensuring that innocent parties do not fall victim to collective punishment for crimes that are a matter of individual responsibility.
speaker: Mr. Seck
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The delegation of Senegal would have therefore liked the resolution to take into account the sometimes difficult situations faced by States concerned with regard to carrying out investigations and enquiries.
speaker: Mr. Seck
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: My delegation regrets that several of the concerns we voiced with a view to making the text more balanced were not reflected in the resolution.
speaker: Mr. Seck
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: However, Senegal's commitment to the zero-zolerance policy called for by the Secretary-General remains absolute, given that the fight against impunity must remain a collective and universal exigency.
speaker: Mr. Seck
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: New Zealand voted in favour of resolution 2272 (2016) because of the clear and pressing need for more robust action to combat sexual exploitation and abuse.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: New Zealand respects the sacrifice and commends the meaningful contribution of the vast majority of United Nations peacekeepers.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The measures in this resolution support the Secretary-General's efforts with respect to sexual exploitation and abuse, in particular to address the systemic failure represented by the ongoing allegations.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The past 10 years, and especially this past year, have demonstrated that the status quo is neither working nor acceptable.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Security Council has a responsibility to act on sexual exploitation and abuse and address the negative consequences of the peacekeeping operations that we members of the Council mandate, including to implement the standards we have all agreed.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We encourage all partners to work together going forward.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Only our close cooperation to implement zero tolerance and build capacity, with a real investment of political will, can make the difference that is so desperately needed for the victims, United Nations peacekeeping, and the credibility of the Organization.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Japan voted in favour of resolution 2272 (2016), proposed by the United States.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Since we spoke on our views on sexual exploitation and abuse in the Chamber yesterday (see S/PV.7642), I wish to emphasize only one point, which is why we think that this resolution is important and necessary.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Japan supports the Secretary-General's decision to repatriate contingents when there is a demonstrated pattern of misconduct.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That measure is aimed not at pointing a finger at contingents, but at protecting civilians where peacekeepers are deployed.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Its purpose is also to urge troop- and police-contributing countries to take action.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We need to realize that investigating allegations of sexual exploitation and abuse is the primary responsibility oftroop- and police-contributing countries, and they have to take appropriate actions against the allegations and hold personnel accountable for sexual exploitation and abuse.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In doing so, the United Nations will ensure that its peacekeepers, who are sometimes the last hope for people suffering in conflicts, are deployed to protect people.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: By taking the appropriate actions, they can also preserve the honour of the vast majority of peacekeepers from Africa, the Asia-Pacific, Latin America and the Caribbean, and Europe, including my own country, Japan, which are fulfilling their tasks seriously in difficult circumstances.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is our belief that resolution 2272 (2016) will send a clear message that the Security Council fully supports the zero-tolerance policy called for by the Secretary-General.
speaker: Mr. Yoshikawa
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Uruguay wishes to express its satisfaction for the adoption earlier in this meeting of resolution 2272 (2016).
speaker: Mr. Bermudez
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: At the outset, we want to thank the United States for its timely initiative.
speaker: Mr. Bermudez
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Uruguay is very pleased to join the rest of the Council in their agreement that dealing with this problem can no longer be postponed.
speaker: Mr. Bermudez
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: With regard to the content of the resolution, which is in line with the concept of zero tolerance, in our dual capacity as a member of the Security Council and a troop-contributing country, we believe that, although the text could be further improved, given the sensitivity ofthe issue, it nonetheless has important provisions for combating such reprehensible acts, which, as was said in yesterday's meeting on the subject (see S/PV.7642), affect not only the image and credibility of United Nations peacekeeping operations but, above all, have an impact on the dignity of the victims who suffer, often irreversibly, from their consequences.
speaker: Mr. Bermudez
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: For all of those reasons, therefore, Uruguay voted in favour of the resolution.
speaker: Mr. Bermudez
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Lastly, we would like to reiterate that all staffwho the Security Council, must be held accountable for are part of United Nations peacekeeping operations, their actions.
speaker: Mr. Bermudez
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: whether military, police or civilian components, just like all personnel in other operations authorized by The meeting rose at 4.10pm.
speaker: Mr. Bermudez
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I thank the briefers for their insights and I welcome Ms. Paleki Ayang to the Council.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We should hear the voices of women activists from civil society in the Chamber more often.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I would like to begin with the words of another activist, Nobel Laureate Leymah Gbowee.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In 2003, her group Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace successfully pressed Charles Taylor to attend peace talks.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Talking afterwards, she said, "We are now taking this stand to secure the future of our children, because we believe, as custodians of society, tomorrow our children will ask us, 'Mama, what was your role during the crisis?"' "What was your role during the crisis?"
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The answer to that question for so many women in Africa is not negotiator; it is not envoy; it is not delegate even, and that needs to change.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is not just about ending gender inequality.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is not just a women's issue; it is a peace issue.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: When women's voices are heard in peace processes, in negotiations and in State-building, the chances of a lasting peace increase.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: If we are serious about truly resolving conflicts and preserving peace - not just for hours, but for generations - we must heed the words of Leymah Gbowee and our briefer Paleki Ayang.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: They demonstrate just how powerful community-based activism can be.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Just think how powerful those women's voices could have been had they actually been in the room at key times in peace processes.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: So, whether in Africa or in any other part of the world, we need to make sure that women are playing the fullest role in conflict resolution.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I am proud that all future United Kingdom-hosted peacebuilding events will ensure that women's voices are heard.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: If the rest of the Council were to follow suit, then we would send a strong message to the rest of the world.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: To support that effort, we have to increase women's participation in politics and society.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That means delivering on the commitments we made in resolutions 1325 (2000), 1889 (2009), 2242 (2015) and so many others because breaking down barriers facing women in peace talks requires breaking down barriers facing women across society.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It means helping girls stay in school, improving health care and, yes, tackling sexual Violence.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: At its heart, it is about ending discrimination against women.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We all have a part to play.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In Somalia, the United Kingdom is helping make health services available to over 1 million Somali women and children, but also providing legal assistance to thousands of Somali women and will soon be supporting initiatives that boost their participation in politics too.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: But this issue will not be solved by one country alone.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is why the United Kingdom is contributing $1 million to the Global Acceleration Instrument for Women, Peace and Security and Humanitarian Action (GAI).
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: By funding the GAI, we can all offer material support that can break down those barriers.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In Burundi, a network of women mediators was able to deal with 5,200 local conflicts in 2015.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is over 14 a day.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Thanks to the GAI, they are now scaling up their activities.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: At a time when the Council has been so frustrated by the crisis in Burundi, it is heartening to see how powerful women's civil society can be in their local mediation efforts.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Ultimately, however, supporting this effort requires more than just our money.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: When the Council visited Mali, Guinea Bissau and Senegal earlier this month, there was not a single female representative of the Council on the trip.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: And even at Headquarters in New York, only two of the 15 Security Council member countries are represented by a woman at this debate.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Since we call upon Africa's leaders to do more to bring women into conflict prevention and resolution, let us also heed the call ourselves.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: What signal does it send when the primary body for preserving international peace and security only has one woman among its 15 permanent representatives.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: What message does it send to that young girl in Somalia who dreams of becoming president, or to those who want to answer the question "What was your role?" with something other than "survivor"?
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: If we want half of the world's population to have a say in conflict prevention and resolution, then let us begin in this building.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is why the United Kingdom has been clear that we need as many credible women as possible to apply to be the next Secretary-General.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have had three so far
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: and I hope that there are more to come.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is time to make history and bring about a historic moment that is long overdue.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: All things being equal, we hope that this will be the year that we appoint a woman to be Secretary-General for the first time.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: When asked "What was your role?", she will be able to say that she was at the forefront of the United Nations action to prevent conflict and resolve crisis and represent the entire world, notjust half of it.
country: United Kingdom Of Great Britain And Northern Ireland
speaker: Mr. Rycroft
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I thank you, Madam President, for chairing and organizing this open debate and I thank Under-Secretary-General Mlambo-Ngcuka for her briefing and her stewardship of UN-Women.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I would like to extend a special thanks also to Ms. Paleki Ayang for her briefing on the perspective of civil society.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Indeed, I thank all five rule 39 briefers for their very useful perspectives this morning.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Today's debate provides us all with an excellent opportunity to take stock of the implementation of the women and peace and security agenda in Africa.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Quite frankly, I hope today's session will do much more than that.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: This debate should also help more women gain positions of leadership and seats at the negotiating table where issues of peace and security are decided, especially as women and girls face more complex and emerging threats, including those posed by the harsh reality of terrorism and violent extremism.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text:
It is undeniable that some progress on the women and peace and security agenda has been made across Africa since the adoption of resolution 1325 (2000)
in 2000.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We appreciate the efforts of the 18 African countries that have developed national action plans that seek to institutionalize the greater participation of women throughout government and society.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: But there is still much work to be done.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I would like to suggest three areas where we should redouble our efforts: first, in helping women overcome systemic obstacles to political participation; secondly, in addressing gender-based violence; and, thirdly, in tranlating the women and peace and security norms established by the Security Council into concrete success in the real world.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: When women actively participate at all levels of political decision-making, we know that we are all safer, that our efforts at peacebuilding are stronger and that around the world Constitutions and peace agreements are more inclusive, just and lasting.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: But women in Africa continue to face, and to overcome, systemic obstacles to their political participation at all levels of decision-making.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In February 2013, for example, 11 countries in the Great Lakes region of Africa signed a peace accord to address decades of violence in eastern areas of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework for the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the Region was a landmark document to be sure.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: But it was also negotiated and adopted without any women having participated in the negotiations.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The technical committees formed to oversee the implementation and the monitoring of the agreement also did not include any women.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In March 2013, recognizing the absence of women in the formal process, the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region convened consultations with women leaders and civil society groups across the region, seeking to link their community-level effort in building peace to the regional and the national implementation committees.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In January 2014, the Great Lakes Women's Plaform for the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework was launched by the Special Envoy, and it provides grants to women's organizations already working to implement peace in the region.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We applaud the dedicated leadership by the United Nations and the countries of the Great Lakes region for recognizing that women were missing from the table and for taking the steps necessary to change that.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: A second area where we need to re-aim our focus is in identifying and addressing gender-based violence in a systemic way.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The long-term success of peace processes depends upon greater respect for human rights and improved prospects for development.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Where gender-based violence is a major feature of conflict or has escalated in the aftermath thereof, it poses a unique challenge to peacebuilding efforts.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In other words, it bears repeating that gender equality is a security issue, and thus a strategic imperative for the Council's work.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: More often than ever before, we are confronted with the unspeakable: the egregious use by violent extremist groups, such as Boko Haram and the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant, of gender-based violence, not to mention kidnapping and slavery, which are strategically employed to achieve their aims.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The abduction of over 250 Chibok girls from a school in northern Nigeria by Boko Haram militants in April 2014 and that militant group's ongoing use of women and girls as suicide bombers remain tragic reminders of how extremist groups are manipulating gender to achieve their ends.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As the international community responds to violence extremist threats, including across Africa, we must ensure that the needs and the perspectives of women and girls most affected by extremist violence are integrated into our larger approach to countering violent extremism.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our efforts to support survivors of gender-based violence across Africa will be incomplete unless we also commit to fighting impunity.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is for that reason that the United States has supported mobile courts in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, which has led to 1,924 trials and 1,336 convictions of gender-based violence since 2009.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: United States assistance has also supported the training of 5,505 providers of services to survivors, strengthened 1,103 local organizations serving gender-based violence-affected populations and provided 20,125 gender-based violence survivors with a holistic package oflegal services.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The third point that I would like to stress today is that the Security Council's active engagement remains absolutely vital in order to achieve real and tangible gains for women yearning to be included in peace processes, even as we recognize that we still have much work to do.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: A study on assessing women's inclusion and influence on peace processes by the Inclusive Peace and Transition Initiative of the Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies in Geneva revealed that when women have been included in peace processes, as in Burundi, Somalia, Darfur and Kenya in recent years, their inclusion was mainly owing to normative pressure applied by women's groups and their international supporters.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our words and resolutions and debates therefore do have an effect on the ground, where it counts the most.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Let me give just one small example of where the engagement of the international community has had a strong impact - actually, not such a small example, but an important example.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In Sierra Leone a programme sponsored by the United States to strengthen women's local political participation became a strong vehicle for empowing women during the 2014 Ebola outbreak.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The women there leveraged their convening authority to host outreach sessions with health-care providers and local populations on the Ebola response.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The effort ultimately yielded important recommendations for commmunity-led Ebola responses, standards that were adapted by the Government of Sierra Leone.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Despite the significant progress we have made in advancing the women and peace and security agenda in Africa, again, there is still that remains to be done.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As my Secretary of State, John Kerry said, our goal is as simple as it is profound, namely, to empower half the world's population as equal partners in preventing and resolving conflict and building peace in countries threatened and affected by war, violence and insecurity.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is also the commitment that the Council has made, and it is a commitmen that we must all strive even harder to fulfil.
speaker: Ms. Sison
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: China welcomes Angola's initiative to convene this debate.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: China expresses its appreciation to you, Minister Delgado, for presiding over this meeting.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I also wish to thank Ms. Mlambo-Ngcuka, Assistant Secretary-General Zerihoun, Ambassador Kamau and Ambassador Antonio for their briefings.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: China also listened attentively to the statement made by the representative of the South Sudan Women's Empowerment Network.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The current international security situation is complex and challenging.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In particular, regions like Africa and the Middle East have long been mired in war and conflict.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Many women are victims of violence and the threat of terror.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: On the other hand, women are increasingly important players in the prevention and resolution of regional conflicts.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The international community should step up protection of the rights and interests of women in conflict and give women a greater role in conflict prevention and resolution.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: First, we should enhance protection for women in conflict, it is incumbent upon the international community to adopt effective measures to maximize security assurances for women affected by conflict.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In providing humanitarian assistance to conflict areas, we should focus in particular on the needs of women and other vulnerable groups.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The provisions of relevant Council resolutions on the protection of women in conflict must be implemented to the letter.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: United Nations peacekeeping operations should, within the purview of their respective mandates, assist host countries in safeguarding the security of women in conflict and should effectively implement a zero-tolerance policy toward sexual violence.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Secondly, greater efforts should be deployed to find political solutions to critical regional issues, and greater importance attached to the role of women in conflict resolution.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The international community should work hard to help design political solutions to conflicts and overcome differences through dialogue.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women should be encouraged to become important players in mediation and to fully leverage their advantages in advocating a culture of peace.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: United Nations peacekeeping operations may also steadily raise the percentage of female staff so that communication with local women and girls can be improved.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Thirdly, women should be given a greater role to play in building a culture of harmony and inclusiveness.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The international community should encourage women to play a greater role in social life, and it should educate young people so that they can resist the ideological influence of violent extremism and the demagogic rhetoric of armed groups and terrorists.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women should be empowered to fully participate in all phases of post-conflict reconstruction, actively encourage the disarmament, demobilization and reintegration process of combatants, and provide counselling and community support for victims of violence.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Fourthly, women must be enabled to promote economic and social development, thereby eliminating the roots causes ofconflict.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The international community should step up economic empowerment efforts for African women, help African countries reduce poverty and promote economic development.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: African women should be provided with better occupational-skills training and with greater funding support for entrepreneurship in order to comprehensively improve incomes and livelihoods, with a view to promoting the industrialization and agricultural modernization of the continent, thereby eradicating the root causes of conflict.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Last September, the Global Summit of Women was convened under a joint China-United Nations initiative.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Summit was attended by Chinese President Xi Jinping and representatives from over 140 countries, including 85 Heads of State and Government.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The event had a significant and far-reaching impact on the development of the global women's cause.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: China decided to contribute $10 million to the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Over the next five years, China will adopt a series of initiatives to help developing countries overcome the difficulties facing women and girls with regard to their access to medical care and education, strengthen training for local women and, through a fund created in partnership with the United Nations, roll out projects dedicated to capacity-building for womin developing countries.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: China attaches great importance to working with Africa, promoting the cause of women and intensifying support for African women in the political, economic, cultural, educational and health domains.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The 2015 Johannesburg Action Plan of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation called for intensified pragmatic cooperation between China and Africa in the area of women's affairs and for dialogue between female leaders.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The assistance provided by China in recent years covers almost all African countries.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: China also provided women and girls in Ebola-afflicted West African countries, such as Sierra Leone and Liberia, with a large amount of assistance in kind to support Africa's efforts to upgrade its public-health system and emergency-response capacity on all fronts.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Going forward, China will implement 200 Happy Life projects across Africa and 100 village-level agricultural development projects, build industrial parks and vocational training centres on a collaborative basis, and provide training for 200,000 technical specialists.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: These cooperative projects will benefit the people of Africa, and in particular bring new opportunities and new hope for the development of African women, thereby creating new conditions for conflict resolution.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: China stands ready to continue working with the international community to jointly help women achieve comprehensive development and fully engage in political, economic and social life so that they can contribute more positive energy to the peace, development and prosperity of the African continent and makes their own important contributions.
speaker: Mr. Liu Jieyi
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I should like to take this opportunity to thank Angola for organizing this important debate, and Minister Delgado for presiding over it.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We also thank the briefers for their insights.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have made significant progress in the 15 years since the Security Council adopted its landmark resolution 1325 (2000) on women and peace and security.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The fundamental importance of addressing the impact of conflict on women and girls is now widely acknowledged.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have agreed frameworks in place.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: However, practical implementation lags behind, particularly with women's participation in conflict prevention and resolution processes.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Meaningful participation is the exception rather than the rule.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That was evident at last week's open debate on conflict prevention in the Great Lakes region (see S/PV.7653).
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Empirical evidence confirms that the meaningful participation of women during all stages of conflict resolution contributes strongly to preventing escalation and sustaining peace.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Including women works.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Failure to include women in peace processes perpetuates inequality.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It makes breaking the cycle of conflict more difficult.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We know this, and yet we continue to hear arguments that women's participation is peripheral rather than essential.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We hear cultural justifications for the exclusion of women from the negotiating table or mediation roles, and we are asked to delay women's involvement until the reconciliation phase, often after an agreement has been reached.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: These outdated attitudes and approaches must be challenged.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Highlighting examples of how women have made a difference in preventing and resolving conflict in Africa demonstrates the practical benefits of women's participation.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Take, for example, the role that women's groups continue to play in de-escalating and preventing election-related violence.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The establishment of women's situation rooms and the deployment of trained female election monitors in Senegal, Kenya, Nigeria and, most recently, in the Central African Republic have had a measurable impact on preventing, monitoring and mitigating incidents of violence and intimidation.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women's groups also play a key role in de-escalating crises and advocating for an end to conflict.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The critical role played by the movement Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace in ending the conflict in that country is well documented.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women have also mobilized to support peace in Burundi by bringing parties together to engage in dialogue.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: A nationwide network of women mediators, established by the United Nations in close partnership with the Ministry of the Interior and civil society organizations, has effectively prevented violence at the local level, dispelled false rumours and mitigated the impact of the ongoing political crisis on everyday people.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As the mediation process in Burundi moves forward, those gains must not be side-lined or suppressed.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The efforts of those women, undertaken with minimal resources and at personal risk, deserve more than our applause; they deserve support and empowerment, because what they do works.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have taken particular note ofthe steps called for by Ms. Paleki Ayang to end sexual violence in South Sudan as a necessary ingredient to rebuilding peace in her country.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We must facilitate the active contribution of women in peace operations in Africa.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We must ensure that United Nations operations are appropriately prepared and equipped to address the needs of women and girls in conflict and post-conflict settings.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: New Zealand lies far from the African continent, however we strive to make a modest, practical contribution to those efforts.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: New Zealand has long reflected women and peace and security considerations in its doctrine, policy and training for uniformed personnel serving internationally.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Last November, an all-female New Zealand Defence Force team provided training on the the theme "Operationalization of gender" at the Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Centre in Ghana.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The training incorporated conflict-prevention techniques through the inclusion of women, increasing the employment of women in conflict prevention and resolution processes, and women's experiences of leadership in conflict.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our experience in gender-sensitive approaches to community policing in post-conflict settings has proved the value of women's participation.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Female police officers interact better with the local female population.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The presence of female personnel empowers local women, thereby ensuring that they are not seen only as victims but as actors and providers of safety and security.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Regional leadership has played an important role in African efforts to support the role of women in conflict prevention and resolution.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We commend the African Union's Gender, Peace and Security Programme.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It has framed the integration and strengthening of the African peace and security architecture's responsiveness to gender issues.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Finally, we urge the Security Council to incorporate the perspectives of women in its work as a matter of course.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We should encourage greater participation by women in all mediation efforts and conflict-prevention processes.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is simple: when women are included as active participants, there is a far greater chance of ending conflict and sustaining peace.
speaker: Mrs. Schwalger
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Through you, Madam President, France would like warmly to thank the delegation of Angola for organizing this open debate, which allows the Security Council, in the context of its work on the prevention and resolution of conflicts, to continue to add value to and to promote the crucial role of women on these issues.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I also thank all the briefers for their precise and enlightening briefings on the evolution of the role of women and, I would even say, the real and potential power they possess in terms of settling conflict in Africa.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I heard the statistics and the information presented by the Executive Director of UN-Women, and the message is clear: women's involvement in these issues is crucial for achieving lasting peace.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The growing recognition of this fact is an important trend for the Organization, a deep-rooted movement in whose favour France is firmly committed.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our efforts should therefore focus on the ways in which to concretely implement that principle.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: What tools not only to strengthen but also ensure active participation by women in the prevention and settlement of conflicts?
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: How can we ensure that all Council resolutions - from 1325 (2000) to 2242 (2015) - are fully and effectively implemented?
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I will try to answer those questions by stressing three points today.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: First, the decision-making power of women in peace processes must be enhanced by facilitating the participation of civil society.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I remind everyone in the Chamber today that civil society is an indispensable force essential to any democratic process, and therefore to every post-conflict stabilization process.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is a simple equation: without Civil society there is no inclusivity and, without that, there can be no lasting peace.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is therefore necessary that Governments open the doors to organizations representing women, if they want to lay the foundation for sustainable development.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We are convinced that in our fight against climate change, women will play a decisive role.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: During the Council's visit to Mali, we noted the wealth and dynamism of Malian civil society.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Let us heed it, because it has something to say about the peace process under way.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Its expertise and analysis can serve as a valuable guide to the implementation of the second national action plan for women and peace and security in Mali, which aims to involve women in the peace process.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The support provided by UN-Women and the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali is essential.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: On a regional level, France also encourages the African Union to continue its efforts to give more space to women through its Gender, Peace and Security Programme, which the African Union Special Envoy on Women, Peace and Security Ms. Bineta Diop, spoke about compellingly.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: France also calls for the full participation of women in all ongoing and future peace processes and dialogues in Africa.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: What goes for Mali also applies to Burundi, the Great Lakes region and the Sahel region.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is a real priority.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Finally, at the national level, France is working closely with civil society.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: During the sixtieth session of Commission on the Status of Women, which came to an end a few days ago, Ms. Laurence Rossignol, France's Minister for Families, Children and Women's Rights, incorporated into her delegation nearly 20 organizations representing women.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In France, civil society is an integral part of women's rights diplomacy.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Secondly, the role of women in the prevention and settlement of conflicts should be increased as part of our strategies against violent extremism and terrorism.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The African continent was tragically and repeatedly struck by the recent attacks in Mali, Cote d'Ivoire and Burkina Faso, as well as by the constant deadly attacks of Boko Haram in Nigeria and Al-Shabaab in Somalia in particular.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We know women are victims of intolerable violence on a daily basis that is an affront to the human conscience.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Terrorist groups target them, exploit them, reduce them to sexual objects and sell them in public squares or online.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women are objects of a parallel economy, victims of human trafficking for sexual exploitation purposes and the trafficking in them finances the activities of terrorist groups.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is the very condition of women and their rights, which are denied.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Above all, we must give women the means to reverse that logic of control, so they can make decisions about their bodies, their lives and the society in which they live.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: To do that, women must have access, including in conflict situations in Africa, to sexual and reproductive rights and health services, to education and economic resources.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women are not just victims of terrorist groups; they have multiple roles to play.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I am convinced that the women and peace and security agenda must be fully integrated into counter-terrorism strategies.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The fight against terrorism and violent extremism is a common undertaking and, to be effective, no stakeholder should be neglected.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women are an integral part of the fight against terrorism and it is essential to provide them with the necessary means to play their parts.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Finally, and thirdly, we must redouble our efforts to reintegrate women associated with armed groups.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women who have suffered the violence of conflict are often marked by a considerable post-conflict stress: they bear the stigma of sexual violence.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We must ensure that they are able to return to their societies and their communities of origin.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That return is often violent.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Husbands, families and the labour market all reject them.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Therefore, it is crucial that women who are liberated from those armed groups should enjoy -just like men or soldiers - disarmament, demobilization and reintegration (DDR) programmes.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Similarly, it is necessary for security sector reform (SSR) programmes implemented in post-crisis situations to take into account women and gender issues.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Without that proper rehabilitation, women will remain marginalized and represent a gap in the rebuilding of societies.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is time for DDR and SSR to become more female-oriented.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is why France, within the framework of its national women and peace and security programme, covering the period 2015-2018, has contributed to several programs in Africa, devoted to, among other things, social cohesion, education, access to justice for women in post-conflict situations on the continent.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The future of Africa is in the hands of its people, especially its women.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Today they continue to be victims of the conflicts ravaging the continent, and it is therefore up to the United Nations to give them the tools to serve as stakeholders in the peace of tomorrow.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Council can count on the full support of France to assist women in post-conflict situations in Africa.
speaker: Mr. Delattre
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our delegation would like to start by expressing its gratitude to the Angolan presidency for its initiative in convening today's meeting on the topic of the role of women in preventing and settling conflicts in Africa.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We would also like to convey our gratitude to all the invited briefers for their participation in the meeting and their comprehensive contribution to the debate.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: One of the most important preconditions for the stability, sustainable development of African countries and security and well-being of the population, including women, isthe prevention and settlement of conflicts.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Despite the overall decline over the past decade, the African continent remains highly vulnerable to crises.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Therefore, a timely and effective response by the international community to emerging threats and security challenges in Africa is essential.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In that regard, we view as unacceptable attempts to dictate to African Governments settlement recipes without their consent or request.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We welcome the increased activity by Africans themselves with regard to emergency response, as well as the growing participation by African women in peacekeeping and peacebuilding efforts.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We note the progress made in forging an African peace and security architecture with the assistance of the international community.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Russian Federation is carrying out a consistent policy of developing cooperation among the United Nations, the African Union and subregional organizations.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We call for further pooling of efforts regarding the conflict situations in Darfur, Somalia, South Sudan, the Central African Republic, Mali, the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Guinea-Bissau, as well as the intra-Sudanese track, in the fight against international terrorism, transnational organized crime, piracy, the illegal trafficking in arms and drugs, as well as other important areas of cooperation, including the issue of women and peace and security.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Russia is ready to step up its cooperation with African States aimed at strengthening their crisis-response capacities, including through the ongoing training of their peacekeepers and law-enforcement agents in Russian educational establishments.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our country is participating in a number of United Nations peacekeeping operations on the continent and plays a leading role among the contributors of air-transport services to them.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The issue of women and peace and security is an inalienable component of peace and conflict-resolution processes and post-conflict peacebuilding.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The participation ofwomen in such efforts has much positive potential.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We must also note the efforts of specialized subregional and regional organizations in that regard.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: A good example of cooperation is the African Union's five-year Gender, Peace and Security Programme for the period 2015-2020.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In order to achieve results in implementing the agenda on women and peace and security, there needs to be a balanced, system-wide approach that provides for the full-fledged participation of women in peace processes throughout the continent and in post-conflict reconstruction.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: No less pressing is the need to ensure the effectiveness of efforts to deal with violence against women during armed conflicts in Africa.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: There is also a need to ensure that the inclusion of gender aspects in our work on the ground does not become an end in itself and is not only declarative in nature.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We should aim at achieving real results.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In that context, it is important to bear in mind that national plans of action for the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000) cannot be used as an instrument for assessing the policy of States in terms of their gender-promotion policies.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We need to bear in mind that the protection of women during the course of armed conflicts and steps to afford them equal opportunities for participation in efforts to achieve peace and security are the primary responsibility of the States involved in such conflicts.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The international community and the United Nations must provide them assistance in that regard.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: One of the main objectives of peacekeeping and peacebuilding efforts should be the restoration of normal life and the elimination of the consequences of conflicts, as well as safeguarding the security of all strata and groups of the population.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As we have noted earlier, greater effectivness of the work of the Security Council is not always achieved through the establishment of new structures.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That is the reason for our doubts with regard to the usefulness of setting up the Informal Experts Group on Women, Peace and Security.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We stand ready to cooperate with other members of the Council on this very important topic in order to develop effective and tried methods.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The women of African States can make a substantive and unique contribution to achieving the objective of preventing and resolving conflicts on the African continent through the joint efforts of all interested parties, as there is a need to create the optimal conditions for achieving that goal, while not forgetting the central task of protecting African women and their safety and security.
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The main guidelines in that regard remain the provisions of resolution 1325 (2000).
speaker: Mr. Zagaynov
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I would like to welcome Ms. Maria Filomena Lobao Telo Delgado and to thank Angola for having convened this extremely important debate on women and peace and security in Africa.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I would also like to thank the Assistant Secretary-General, the Executive Director of UN-Women, the Chair of the Peacebuilding Commission, the Observer of the African Union and the Executive Director of South Sudan Women's Empowerment Network.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Over the past 15 years, the Security Council has managed to build a legal framework for the programme of action for women and peace and security through the adoption of resolution 1325 (2000) and seven subsequent resolutions.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Council accordingly established a concrete political momentum thanks to which the contribution of women to the prevention and resolution of conflicts in Africa has significantly grown.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That momentum has also helped reinforce the contribution of women through a number of mechanisms and legal frameworks that have been adopted in Africa in order to boost the participation of women in this area.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As examples, I may point to the Solemn Declaration on Gender Equality in Africa and the appointment of an African Union Special Envoy on Women, peace and security.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: And in West Africa there have been numerous positive experiences.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: While innovative methods have been found, they remain on the sidelines and have not been fully exploited within official frameworks.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The conclusions that were adopted by the Commission on the Status ofWomen this past Friday affirmed the need for the participation of women in conflict prevention and resolution.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: They also affirmed the importance of the implementation of the Beijing Programme of Action and of achieving genuine, comprehensive gender equality.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Those frameworks and mechanisms are very important, but to date they have not ensured the required level of participation.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: On that account, I would like to share the following remarks.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Mr. Gaspar Martins took the Chair.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: First, Egypt supports the call of the Secretary-General to strengthen the role of women in peacekeeping activities, mediation and the prevention of conflicts.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That call was supported by the three major reviews carried out recently in that area.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have also seen tangible evidence of the importance of the role of women in their countries, especially in Liberia, Malawi and Central Africa, where women are successfully governing.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Second, there are large gaps in terms of the Council's resolutions and their follow-up.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We therefore need to adopt a methodology that will enable us to bridge those gaps so as to ensure the comprehensive implementation of those resolutions.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We also need to step up the role of the Informal Experts Group set up in resolution 2242 (2015).
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Third, several questions continue to be absent from our debate, such as the suffering of women who are living under foreign occupation.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I point out also the exaggeration of the link with human rights and international humanitarian law, because it weakens the means for providing available protection in times of peace as well as in times of war.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I reiterate that there is the problem of politicizing some of the issues linked to the two regimes of international law that I have mentioned.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: There are also problems with regard to the infringement of national sovereignty, and sometimes we rely on information that is unofficial and lacking precision.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That distracts our attention from the issues that concern us, to their detriment, in particular the participation of women in conflict prevention and resolution.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Fourth, problems and weaknesses persist with regard to the appointment of women to senior level and leadership posts in political missions.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Fifth, our programme of action completely fails to take into account cultural particularities in its implementation, which negatively affects the participation of women in conflict prevention and resolution.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Sixth, it is important that discussions continue within the Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations, so that we can confront the challenges and problems standing in the way of the full participation of women in peacekeeping activities.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Seventh, Egypt is about to adopt a strategy on gender equality, and we very much welcome the statement made by Ambassador Macharia Kamau earlier, since the strategy to be adopted by the Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations can be an excellent starting point for bolstering the participation of women in conflict prevention and resolution, particularly in terms of action at the regional level.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Egypt attaches great importance to issues affecting the role of women in conflict prevention and resolution.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We are devoting major efforts at the national level to improve the status and empowerment of women.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text:
We have supported the substance of resolution 1325 (2000)
since its adoption.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That resolution is an important milestone with regard to the status of women and their participation in the resolution of conflicts.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Egypt was one of the first countries to adhere to resolution 2242 (2015)
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: this past October.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The national council responsible for the status of women in Egypt has fine-tuned a national plan of action based on resolution 1325 (2000).
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Egypt thus became one of 17 African countries to have a national plan of action of that kind.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Egypt has also organized a number of events concerning this issue since the adoption of resolution 1325 (2000) 15 years ago.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We attribute great importance to capacity-building.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The regional centre in Cairo responsible for specialized training in peacekeeping in Africa has held seven training workshops and two training workshops for trainers.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The main topic ofthose workshops was the social dimension of peacekeeping and peacebuilding in implementing resolution 1325 (2000) between 2013 and 2015.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Five other workshops are due to be held in June.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Egypt is fully committed to this process and to implementating the plan of action, and takes part in all relevant regional and international forums.
speaker: Mr. Mahmoud
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I now give the floor to the representative of Brazil.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Mr. De Aguiar Patriota (Brazil) Let me congratulate Angola on having organized this debate under the guidance of its Minister for Family and the Promotion of Women, Ms. Maria Filomena Delgado.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I also thank the Executive Director of the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women, the Assistant Secretary-General for Political Affairs, the Chair of the Peacebuilding Commission, the Permanent Observer of the African Union and Ms. Palegi Ayang for their presentations.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Today's debate provides a timely opportunity to reflect on the results of the high-level review of the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000), and to focus on the needs and perspectives of Africa.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Brazil took note with satisfaction of the recommendations of the global study on the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000) and, in particular, its emphasis on prevention and the need to avoid the militarization of the women and peace and security agenda.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As highlighted by the global study, increasing recognition of women's participation and empowerment is an end in itself and should not be part of counterterrorism strategies or efforts to prevent violent extremism conducive to terrorism; rather, it should be a part of the civilian peace agenda.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: That point is highly relevant for Africa, where most peacekeeping operations are deployed and where women's organizations have been playing and will continue to play a positive role in all peace processes, from mediation and prevention initiatives to reconciliation and reconstruction in the aftermath of conflict.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Notwithstanding significant challenges, African women have many success stories to tell.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women's organizations were at the forefront of the Liberian peace process.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Post-conflict recovery initiatives led to the economic empowerment of thousands of women in Burundi and Rwanda.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The policies and instruments of the African Union Gender Policy, as well as the Gender, Peace and Security Programme of the African Peace and Security Architecture, provide valuable tools to support the empowerment of African women as agents of peace.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We also welcome the adoption last year of the African Union Agenda 2063 and its pledge to empower African women in all spheres of social life.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is also heartening to note that three important peacekeeping operations in Africa are now led by women.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We pay tribute to the commitment and leadership of Ellen Margrethe Loj, the Head of the United Nations Mission in South Sudan; Ai'chatou Mindaoudou, the Head of the United Nations Operation in Cote d'Ivoire; and Kim Bolduc, the Head of the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Another woman, Hester Paneras, until recently steered the world's largest international police component - that of the African Union-United Nations Hybrid Operation in Darfur.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Yet this positive trend cannot offset the fact that women constitute merely 4 per cent of the 88,000 troops and police personnel currently deployed in United Nations peacekeeping operations in Africa.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In that regard, we recall resolution 2242 (2015), which calls upon the Secretary-General and Member States to double the number of women in military and police contingents of United Nations peacekeeping operations over the next five years.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Female peacekeepers are uniquely well placed to build trust with local communities and to address sexual and gender-based violence.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: They also serve as role models to inspire women and girls to seek more rights and participation in our societies.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In recognizing and supporting women's role as agents of peace, the international community is also contributing to address one of the direst aspects of war that mostly affects women and girls.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Sexual violence in conflict remains a serious concern for vulnerable populations impacted by war around the world, predominantly women and girls.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Despite the strong African commitment to fighting sexual and gender-based violence, serious crimes against humanity, involving rape and sexual slavery, continue to occur in some regions of Africa.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Brazil strongly condemns these abhorrent violations.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have long upheld the imperative to pursue accountability for serious crimes and abuses against women and girls, including but not limited to sexual and gender-based violence.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: A milestone in this regard was the recent International Criminal Court (ICC) trial, presided over by Brazilian Judge Sylvia Steiner, leading to the conviction of Jean-Pierre Bemba for war crimes and crimes against humanity in the Central African Republic.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: This was the first ICC case to specifically focus on the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war, and should serve as a powerful deterrent to would-be perpetrators.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As the current Chair of the Commission on the Status of Women (CSW), I am deeply committed to gender equality in all political and security processes.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: A specific concern are the human rights of women of African origin, who are often subject to discrimination and prejudice outside Africa.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In this spirit, Brazil and the United States co-organized last week a CSW side event on the racial identity of women of African descent in the diaspora, in the context of the 2015-2024 International Decade for People of African Descent.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We believe that visibility and self-representation are powerful strategies for tackling racism and injustice.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our South-South cooperation with Africa, a key priority of Brazilian foreign policy, is closely aligned with the women and peace and security agenda.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In Guinea-Bissau, we helped enable health institutions to assist women and girl victims of gender-based violence.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, we have financed projects to assist victims of sexual and gender-based violence.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS
