sentence_text: In this respect, I cannot fail to refer to the inspiring work of Dr. Denis Mukwege, a physician who has treated thousands of survivors of rape in Bukavu, Democratic Republic of the Congo, and a role model not just in Africa, but worldwide.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Through the Guinea-Bissau configuration of the Peacebuilding Commission, I have witnessed first-hand the essential role played by women in building sustainable peace.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Brazilian Peace Operations Joint Training Center in Rio de Janeiro regularly holds workshops and courses to train peacekeepers on gender issues and the protection of women, where rigorous standards regarding the conduct and discipline of personnel are upheld.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: At the domestic level, let me highlight the drafting process of our national action plan on women and peace and security.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We are striving to elaborate an effective plan to address the four pillars of the agenda: prevention, protection, participation, and peacebuilding and recovery.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: This will include but will not be limited to measures to increase the percentage of female peacekeepers; to foster the participation of women in all peace and security processes, including in our Foreign and Defence Ministries; to further improve relations between troops and civilians, particularly women and girls, in peacekeeping operations; and to fortify humanitarian assistance and technical cooperation initiatives on gender issues in conflict and post-conflict situations.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Since the women and peace and security agenda is not solely a Government matter, we have established a broad-based working group comprising representatives not only of relevant ministries and the armed forces, but also of academia and civil society, to debate and draft our national action plan.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In conclusion, let me reiterate Brazil's firm commitment to both the promotion of peace in Africa and the crosscutting campaign on gender equality and women's empowerment.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We will continue to advance these inseparable agendas at all levels of the United Nations.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The President: I give the floor to the representative of India.
speaker: Ms. Delgado/Mr. Gaspar Martins
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Allow me to thank the briefers for their insights.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I wish to thank you, Madam President, and your country, Angola, the President of the Security Council for the month of March, for organizing this open debate on the role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflict in Africa, a subject that is close to our hearts in Africa.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: I wish also to extend Namibia's appreciation to you for focusing your presidency on issues that are important to the African continent, the Middle East and other parts of the world - issues that need the Council's renewed attention.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Namibia associates itself with the statement delivered by the representative of the Islamic Republic of Iran on behalf of the Non-Aligned Movement.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: As we focus on this subject matter, it is important to recognize that more must be done to fully engage women in conflict resolution and mediation.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Women's full participation in peacemaking is fundamental to building peace and security.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Charter of the United Nations not only committed its members to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war, but also unequivocally reaffirmed fundamental human rights and the equal rights of men and women.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Despite this strong commitment, the understanding of the impact of armed conflict on women and girls and the role of women in conflict resolution and peacebuilding developed slowly within the United Nations.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Under the presidency of Namibia, the Security Council adopted resolution 1325 (2000) on women and peace and security on 31 October 2000.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The adoption of that resolution marked another milestone in the process of elevating women's role in peace and security to a high political agenda and urged an enhanced role for women in preventing conflict, promoting peace and assisting in post-conflict reconstruction and the incorporation of a gender perspective into United Nations operations.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Through resolution 1325 (2000), the increased participation ofwomen in peace processes was recognized as a goal for the first time in the United Nations history.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It is important to note that through the adoption of resolution 1325 (2000), the conventional impression of women as helpless victims of war was replaced by an understanding of the important role women play in fostering peace and security.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We believe that when women are involved as agents of peace, sexual violence against women and children in war and conflict situations can be addressed.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text:
Resolution 1325 (2000)
is the first-ever resolution adopted by the Security Council that specifically addresses the disproportionate impact of war on women and stresses the significance of women's equal participation and full involvement in all efforts to maintain and promote sustainable peace and security.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Namibia attaches great importance to the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000).
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: In the region of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), Namibia was the first country to ratify the SADC Protocol on Gender and Development in October 2009.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The Protocol calls upon members States to put in place measures to ensure that women have equal representation and participation in key decision-making positions and peacebuilding processes.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: This explains why Namibia contributes one of the largest female contingents to the African Union-United Nations Hybrid Operation in Darfur.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Namibian women in peacekeeping missions have demonstrated remarkable commitment, high competencies and aptitudes for innovation.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Today, Namibian women are also steadily rising through the ranks and expanding their influence at an ever-increasing rate, serving bravely at national, regional and global levels in many different ways.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: More critically, they serve and sacrifice as courageously as any man out there, as they did during our struggle for liberation.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: At the global level, it is high time that we establish and implement an ambitious but achievable agenda for action on women in armed conflict and allow an increased role for women in the peace process.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: The provisions of resolution 1325 (2000) must be framed in State obligations to address structural and systemic gender inequality and discrimination through comprehensive legislation, policies and institutional reforms.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Our work and advocacy should now be aimed at the everyday and we should never give up.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We must succeed, as we cannot afford to fail our next generation of women.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: History has clearly demonstrated that those women who have been afforded the opportunity to participate in peacekeeping missions have shown that courage and leadership recognize no gender, as women who participate in peacekeeping missions do so facing the same risks and are prepared to die, live and lose limbs just like their male counterparts.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text:
We must constantly bear in mind that resolution 1325 (2000)
and subsequent resolutions, especially resolution 2242 (2015), require us to take robust action at the national level to put policies in place that will pave the way for international deployment of female peacekeepers.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Equal to the same task, it is our obligation to implement the recommendations of the global study on resolution 1325 (2000).
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: We have just adopted the new 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (General Assembly resolution 70/1), which encompasses our collective targets that will not only have a life-changing impact on hundreds of millions of women, but will also help to create a better world that is more equitable.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: However, its effective implementation will depend on its simplicity and its transformational power to sanction, within its life span, an immense global response to the most pressing issues of women empowerment and, more importantly, the full participation of women in peace and security.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Resolution 1325 (2000) is for the benefit of the whole human race, and has been intended to be so since its adoption in October 2000.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: It should be regarded as a global objective that reflects peace, equality and development.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS

sentence_text: Its effective implementation in good faith should not be half-hearted.
speaker: Mr. Emvula
Subject: WPS
